title: Últimas Noticias de El Magdalena
content: Las exportaciones de petróleo desde Latinoamérica a Estados Unidos tendrán un impacto negativo del 0,08 % en el producto interior bruto (PIB) de los países ...
resumen:
Las exportaciones de petróleo desde Latinoamérica a Estados Unidos tendrán un impacto negativo del 0,08 % en el producto interior bruto (PIB) de los países exportadores a causa de los aranceles impuestos por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, según proyecciones de la Organización Latinoamericana de Energía (Olade), con sede en Quito.

Las exportaciones energéticas entre América Latina y el Caribe (ALC) y Estados Unidos han visto un crecimiento sin precedentes, hasta alcanzar los 146.587 millones de dólares en 2023, más del doble de los 68.031 millones reportados el año 2020.

Estados Unidos tiene un superávit en el comercio energético con América Latina, con exportaciones que son, al menos, el doble de sus importaciones desde la región.

El 80 % de las exportaciones estadounidenses hacia Latinoamérica son petróleo y derivados, y poco menos del 20 % es gas natural, mientras que casi todas las ventas de América Latina a Estados Unidos son petróleo.

Casi el 10 % de las exportaciones de Latinoamérica a Estados Unidos corresponde a productos energéticos.

Entre las estrategias sugeridas para afrontar esta situación se encuentran la diversificación de mercados, particularmente hacia Europa y Asia, así como el fortalecimiento de proyectos de integración regional.

Se subraya la necesidad de avanzar hacia matrices energéticas más sostenibles y autosuficientes, lo que aumentaría la resiliencia de la región ante posibles crisis externas.

El estudio de Olade subraya la relevancia de establecer políticas preventivas y de diversificación que resguarden los intereses energéticos y económicos de América Latina frente a los cambios en las políticas comerciales de Estados Unidos.

La Olade es un organismo de cooperación, coordinación y asesoría técnica de carácter público e intergubernamental, que desde 1973 busca fomentar la integración, conservación, racional aprovechamiento, comercialización y defensa de los recursos energéticos de la región.

Entre sus integrantes figuran Argentina, Barbados, Belice, Bolivia, Brasil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Ecuador, El Salvador, Granada, Guatemala, Guyana, Haití, Honduras, Jamaica, Perú, República Dominicana, Surinam, Trinidad y Tobago, Uruguay y Venezuela.

title: Secretario del Tesoro de EE.UU. dijo que depende de China dar el primer paso para reducir medidas arancelarias
content: Bessent, secretario del Tesoro, afirmó en una entrevista para CNBC que el hecho de que China haya eximido a algunos productos de los aranceles indica que están interesados en reducir las tensiones.
resumen:
Scott Bessent, secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, indicó que depende de Pekín dar el primer paso para reducir la escalada arancelaria, debido al desequilibrio comercial entre ambos países.
Bessent afirmó en una entrevista para CNBC que China debe desescalar, porque Estados Unidos le vende cinco veces menos de lo que China le vende, por lo que los aranceles del 125% son insostenibles.
Bessent afirmó que el hecho de que China haya eximido a algunos productos de los aranceles indica que están interesados en reducir las tensiones.
Bessent añadió que tiene “una escalera de escalada en la recámara y estamos muy ansiosos por no tener que utilizarla”, y que la escalada podría incluir un embargo.
El secretario del Tesoro también señaló que Estados Unidos ha dejado de lado a China por ahora, mientras busca acuerdos comerciales con 15 y 17 países más.
Bessent añadió que no le sorprendería que un acuerdo comercial con India fuera el primero en anunciarse.
Funcionarios estadounidenses se reunieron con sus homólogos chinos durante las reuniones del FMI y el Banco Mundial en Washington, DC, la semana pasada para hablar sobre “estabilidad financiera”, pero no indicó que surgieran discusiones comerciales durante las conversaciones.

title: Shein sube sus precios en Estados Unidos hasta un 377% ante inminentes aranceles de Trump
content: Esta medida es una primera señal del posible efecto de la guerra comercial sobre los consumidores estadounidenses.
resumen:
Shein Group Ltd subió los precios de sus productos en Estados Unidos, desde vestidos hasta utensilios de cocina, ante los inminentes aranceles sobre los pequeños paquetes.

El precio medio de los 100 principales productos de la categoría de belleza y salud aumentó un 51% con respecto al jueves, y varios de los artículos duplicaron su precio.

En el caso de los productos para el hogar, cocina y los juguetes, el aumento fue de más del 30%, encabezado por un aumento del 377% en el precio de un juego de 10 años de cocina.

Respecto a la ropa de mujer, subió al 8%.

Las plataformas de compra por comercio electrónico como Shein y Temu enfrentan un arancel del 120% sobre muchos de sus productos debido a la decisión del gobierno de Trump de poner fin a la exención de “minimis” para los paquetes pequeños procedentes de China continental y Hong Kong.

Esta semana entrarán en vigor aranceles del 120% también para estos paquetes pequeños, por lo que empresas como Shein y Temu dejarían de beneficiarse de la exención que excluía pagar tasas a los artículos de hasta US$800.

Washington también aumentará la tasa por artículo postal sobre los bienes que entren después del 2 de mayo a US$100 y aún más después del 1 de junio.

title: Secretario del Tesoro de EEUU defiende “incertidumbre estratégica” de aranceles de Trump
content: Estados Unidos y China se encuentran en medio de una guerra comercial de aranceles y Bessent es el funcionario estadounidense que lidera las conversaciones económicas entre los dos países.
resumen: El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, defendió el domingo la política arancelaria del presidente Donald Trump como una forma de crear “incertidumbre estratégica” que da ventaja a Washington. Trump ha impuesto aranceles del 10% a la mayoría de los socios comerciales de Estados Unidos y un impuesto adicional del 145% a muchos productos procedentes de China. Pekín ha respondido con aranceles del 125% a los productos estadounidenses. Decenas de países se enfrentan a un plazo de 90 días que vence en julio para llegar a un acuerdo con Washington y evitar tasas más altas específicas para cada uno. Bessent declaró al programa de noticias “This Week”, de la cadena ABC: “En la teoría de juegos, esto se llama incertidumbre estratégica, no le vas a decir a la otra parte de la negociación dónde terminarás”. Bessent añadió: “Nadie es mejor para generar esta influencia que el presidente Trump”. Washington ha priorizado las conversaciones con aliados clave como Japón, Corea del Sur y Suiza. Trump declaró en una entrevista reciente con la revista Time que el presidente chino, Xi Jinping, lo había llamado para hablar sobre el comercio. Pekín reiteró el sábado que no habían mantenido conversaciones comerciales. Bessent sugirió que China podría negar las conversaciones en curso porque “se dirigen a un público diferente”. El secretario de Estado Marco Rubio se negó a revelar si Trump y Xi habían hablado.

title: Trump sacude el mundo en sus primeros 100 días con una guerra comercial que no se detiene
content: El 2 de abril, bautizado como el ‘Día de Liberación’, Trump se presentaba con un enorme cartón que contenía una tabla de países y aranceles para ser aplicados a decenas de países y territorios.
resumen:
La guerra arancelaria desencadenada por Donald Trump ha supuesto uno de los momentos más disruptivos de los primeros 100 días de su segundo mandato, con impacto global de una magnitud histórica y que podría haber sido mayor de no haber sido contenida por el pánico en los mercados.

El 2 de abril, bautizado como el ‘Día de Liberación’, Trump se presentaba con un enorme cartón con una tabla de países y aranceles aplicados a decenas de países y territorios.

Trump adora los aranceles, la “principal herramienta de la política económica” de su administración, según Alan Deardoff, profesor emérito de política pública y economía de la Universidad de Michigan.

La Casa Blanca impuso una pausa de 90 días en la aplicación de la mayor parte de los aranceles que había anunciado. Solo quedan efectivos los del 25% al acero y aluminio; el 10% a las importaciones de casi todos sus socios; y los del 145% aplicados a los productos chinos.

El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump dio un golpe de timón este miércoles en su guerra comercial con una "pausa" de 90 días en los aranceles aplicados a decenas de países, excepto a China, a la que se los sube al 125% por haber tomado represalias.

El director del Consejo Económico Nacional, Kevin Hasset, confesó que hubo “algo más de urgencia” a la hora de pausar aranceles.

Donald Trump dijo que se ha reunido “con muchos países”, pero no dijo cuántos ni cuáles.

El economista jefe del Fondo Monetario Internacional (FMI), Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas, declaró que se está entrando en una nueva era a medida que se reinicia el sistema económico mundial. El FMI redujo medio punto el crecimiento mundial por la guerra comercial global.

El principal foco de la política arancelaria siempre iba a ser y fue China. Trump vivió jornadas en las que aparecían por sorpresa aumentos de los aranceles a los productos chinos, hasta alcanzar una tasa del 145% sobre la mayoría de bienes del país asiático.

Pekín respondió con sus represalias arancelarias –con tasas a los productos estadounidenses del 125 %–, y el órdago de Trump ha perdido fuelle.

Scott Bessent, secretario del Tesoro, confesó que la guerra comercial, en los términos actuales, es “insostenible”.

Los aranceles a los productos de China iban a bajar “sustancialmente, pero no serán cero”, y prometía que ya están en negociaciones para llegar a un acuerdo.

title: Embajador de China alienta a Perú frente a guerra arancelaria: "Tiene oportunidad para proyectarse al Asia-Pacífico y expandirse"
content: El embajador de China en Perú, Song Yang, destacó las oportunidades que el país tiene para diversificar sus mercados y fortalecer su presencia en el Asia-Pacífico, pese a los desafíos derivados de la ...
resumen:
El embajador de China en Perú, Song Yang, destacó las oportunidades que el país tiene para diversificar sus mercados y fortalecer su presencia en el Asia-Pacífico, pese a los desafíos derivados de la guerra arancelaria.
Song Yang criticó las políticas comerciales de Estados Unidos impuestas por Donald Trump y defendió el fortalecimiento de los lazos económicos bilaterales entre China y Perú.
Song Yang afirmó que la política estadounidense de “aranceles recíprocos” perjudica el orden del comercio económico mundial y socava los intereses de pueblos de todos los países.
Song Yang dijo que los aranceles impuestos “se convierten en impuestos insoportables en la vida diaria”, afectando incluso a las empresas estadounidenses instaladas en China.
Según datos de American Chamber of Commerce in China, hay 73.000 empresas estadounidenses en China, con una inversión acumulada de US$1,2 billones.
Song Yang resaltó que los nuevos aranceles que Estados Unidos le ha impuesto a China, que se elevan a 245%, se convierten "en un mero juego de cifras carente de sentido económico".
Song Yang observó que eso hará que Estados Unidos pierda entre el 35% y 45% de sus ingresos por aranceles.
El diplomático destacó el papel estratégico del megapuerto de Chancay: “Las relaciones entre China y Perú entran en una nueva era histórica con el Puerto de Chancay. La ruta directa bidireccional ‘De Chancay a Shanghái’ solo tarda 23 días y reduce costos logísticos por más de 20%”.
Song Yang enfatizó que el proyecto crea condiciones favorables para que los productos agrícolas de buena calidad del Perú ingresen al mercado chino y mitiguen riesgos arancelarios.
Song Yang enfatizó que Perú tiene enormes potenciales y oportunidades de desarrollo al apoyarse en América Latina, proyectarse al Asia-Pacífico y expandir su presencia global.
Song Yang hizo un llamado al Gobierno peruano para asegurar un marco favorable para las inversiones.
Song Yang valoró la reciente aprobación del proyecto de ley para crear Zonas Económicas Especiales para el sector privado (ZEEP).
Song Yang aseguró que este paso abrirá nuevas puertas para más inversiones chinas.
Song Yang refirió que se compartirán experiencias en la construcción de zonas francas, parques industriales y ZEEP, implementando el empoderamiento científico-tecnológico y la capacitación profesional, creando más oportunidades de empleo para poblaciones locales.
Song Yang reafirmó el compromiso de China con el proyecto de Chancay.

title: How President Trump’s Second Term Is Changing
content: President Trump has wielded the presidency as an instrument of blunt power, ignoring the howls of outrage from Democrats and daring largely docile Republicans to challenge the limits of his authority.
resumen:
In his second term, President Trump is intent on transforming America and its place in the world. He has driven domestic, economic, and foreign policy in new directions, challenged the authority of the courts, and sought to purge liberal influence from government, education, and culture.

**Foreign Policy:**
*   Mr. Trump sent a clear signal about the end of an era of international agreements and norms.
*   He views the world as divided into those that “have the cards” and those that don’t.
*   He seems determined to deal largely with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China.
*   He wanted to switch sides and normalize relations with Moscow.
*   On his first trip abroad in his new term, for Pope Francis’ funeral, Mr. Trump held one detailed conversation, with Mr. Zelensky.

**Immigration:**
*   Mr. Trump rode to re-election on promises to crack down on immigration.
*   He has targeted student visa holders and legal permanent residents who took part in campus protests over the Israel-Hamas war.
*   He has jettisoned due process and sent undocumented immigrants to a megaprison for terrorists in El Salvador.
*   The administration has placed migrants’ names in Social Security’s “death master file” to cut off their access to bank accounts and other financial services.
*   He has fulfilled a signature campaign promise, essentially sealing the southern border with Mexico even as he welcomes white South Africans as refugees.
*   U.S. border officials are using more aggressive tactics, which the administration calls “enhanced vetting,” at ports of entry to the United States.
*   His efforts continue to fall short of the mass deportations he vowed to carry out.

**Federal Government:**
*   Elon Musk and Mr. Trump have a presidential partnership that has turned into a bureaucratic bull rush.
*   Mr. Musk has turned federal agencies inside out.
*   Mr. Musk has sought to cut the number of people drawing a government paycheck by hundreds of thousands.
*   Over 250,000 people have had their jobs cut, planned to be cut or have taken a buyout.
*   Mr. Musk has angered several top Trump officials, including Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.

**Retribution:**
*   Mr. Trump has used his official powers to carry out a retribution campaign against his perceived enemies.
*   His subordinates have fired career prosecutors at the Justice Department who played a role in investigating Mr. Trump or his supporters who rioted at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
*   The president terminated taxpayer-financed security protection for Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and others who went on to criticize Mr. Trump, including John R. Bolton.
*   The president has threatened his perceived opponents with state sanctions.
*   He has urged the Federal Communications Commission to remove the licenses of broadcast networks that have covered him in ways he does not like.
*   Mr. Trump is bullying universities, demanding ideological changes to hiring and academic policies and freezing huge research grants.
*   He has signed executive orders singling out law firms that employed or represented people he considers opponents.
*   He has signed presidential orders that target former officials he dislikes for “reviews” by the federal government, in search of any evidence that could be used to prosecute them.
*   Mr. Krebs has since resigned from his job and said he must focus full time on defending himself.

**Tariffs and Trade:**
*   President Trump unveiled his plans for remaking the global trading system and said the day would be remembered as “Liberation Day.”
*   He added a 10 percent tariff to Chinese exports.
*   In March, he added another 10 percent tariff on Chinese exports.
*   Mr. Trump decided to pause them for 90 days for other countries, but he announced drastically higher rates for Chinese imports.
*   Products from China now face a minimum tariff of 145 percent, and in some cases the levies are much higher. U.S. exports now face a 125 percent tariff going into China.
*   U.S. officials have toyed with the idea for years of “decoupling” from China for national security reasons.

**Economy:**
*   Mr. Trump’s ever-shifting trade policies threaten to drive up consumer prices, disrupt global supply chains and inspire retaliatory tariffs from U.S. trading partners.
*   Mr. Trump’s threats to fire Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, have roiled financial markets.
*   His immigration policies have led some employers to complain that they are struggling to find workers.
*   The administration’s cost-cutting efforts, led by Elon Musk, have resulted in tens of thousands of layoffs and resignations among government workers and put billions of dollars in federal funding in limbo.

**Imperialism:**
*   Mr. Trump revived the phrase manifest destiny for his inaugural address.
*   He has talked about acquiring Greenland, retaking the Panama Canal and turning Canada into the 51st state.

**Diversity and Equity:**
*   Mr. Trump said diversity efforts at the Federal Aviation Administration had lowered standards for air traffic controllers.
*   Mr. Trump equated diversity with incompetence.
*   On his first day back in office, Mr. Trump signed an executive order that required the elimination of all D.E.I. programs, personnel and practices.

**Culture:**
*   President Trump made himself chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
*   He fired board members who had been appointed by Democrats.
*   Mr. Trump complained that the center’s programming had become too “wokey.”
*   Mr. Trump also took aim at the Smithsonian Institution.
*   The humanities endowment canceled most of its grants and made plans to redirect some resources toward Mr. Trump’s priorities.
*   The arts endowment announced that it would require organizations seeking grants to promise not to promote “diversity, equity and inclusion” or “gender ideology.”

**Social Media:**
*   One of the defining characteristics of the second Trump administration is how so many of its top officials behave like influencers.
*   There is a constant cascade of content meant for social media consumption.
*   Mr. Trump has often sought to create his own versions of reality, taking steps to constrain independent news coverage while amplifying the voices of influencers and openly supportive outlets he has invited into his orbit.

title: Trump’s ‘chaos’ a tactical move
content: With US President Donald Trump celebrating his (second) 100th day in the Oval Office today, economists are of the opinion that a meeting, sooner rather than later, between him and Chinese counterpart ...
resumen:
With US President Donald Trump celebrating his (second) 100th day in the Oval Office, economists believe a meeting between him and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping could boost global trade, especially for smaller economies like Malaysia, which are "caught in the middle" of the tariff war. Trump's stance on tariffs seems to be softening. Malaysia's negotiating team, led by Trade, Investment and Industry Minister Tengku Datuk Seri Zafrul Abdul Aziz, is in discussions with Trump’s representatives.

Economist Geoffrey Williams believes Trump's strategies are successful, with at least 75 countries focused on reducing trade barriers. He said reciprocal tariffs are a tactic to get countries to the negotiating table, which has worked well, and will likely yield healthier long-term trade relations. He also said this helps slow US national debt, which currently stands in excess of US$36 trillion, as the tariffs encourage the relocation of some production back to the United States.

The managing director of a listed tourism entity sees the "chaos" as a tactical move by Trump and is optimistic that a discussion between President Trump and President Xi should materialise before the 90-day tariff pause expires.

Bank Muamalat Malaysia Bhd chief economist Mohd Afzanizam Abdul Rashid believes the United States has valid grounds to complain about international trade practices and should resort to the World Trade Organisation (WTO). He noted that consumer confidence and business sentiment in the Unites States are on the decline.

Sunway University’s economics professor Dr Yeah Kim Leng noted that the deterioration of the US economy is likely to force Trump to scale back his tariffs.

An economist with an international research house said there is a moderate chance Trump could soften his tariff stance toward Malaysia, particularly if Malaysia negotiates concessions like increased US imports or market access during the 90-day pause. She said Trump’s focus on trade deficits and domestic political pressures make a full exemption unlikely without significant trade balance adjustments. Significant economic challenges from the 24% tariff imposed on Malaysia that is currently paused at 10% would include reduced export competitiveness, potential job losses, and slower gross domestic product growth. Key industries such as electrical and electronics, machinery, and palm oil are most vulnerable, though semiconductor exemptions provide relief.

title: Trump's second term presents uncertain economic outlook, economist says
content: Jeff Bush has been watching the ups and downs of the worldwide economy for more than 30 years. Even he didn't know exactly what to make of President Donald Trump's tariff war.
resumen:
Economic expert Jeff Bush presented his forecast for rubber and manufacturing under Donald Trump's second term, as part of the NAHAD annual conference in Tampa, Fla., in April.

Bush has been watching the ups and downs of the American economy for more than 30 years.

Trump promised tariffs on several countries, with China being the biggest tariff target.

Bush spoke to rubber industry executives on April 14 during the annual NAHAD conference in Tampa.

One of his central messages: Trump's second term and tariff plan will usher in serious deviations from the political and fiscal norm, and all industries, not just rubber, should be prepared.

The current tariff rate on China sits at 145 percent according to Bush.

The New York Times reported that as of April 12, Chinese goods are now a total of 2.45 times higher priced than they were before Trump's tariff war began.

Bush said many American business owners are planning on pausing or slowing production.

Trump's second term began earlier this year.

Trump had a four-year hiatus away from the Oval Office from 2021-25.

2024's promises included tariffs, a heavier reliance on fossil fuels and mass immigrant deportations.

Bush said that Trump is a unique president because he "actually tries to do what he campaigned on."

Bush said that Trump's 2024 campaign promises included exploiting the tremendous fossil fuel reserves.

Bush highlighted Congress's year-long quest for tax reform throughout 2025.

Bush said the U.S. federal debt grew by $1.3 trillion in 2024, with the total debt now surpassing $36 trillion as of April 2025.

The debt is expected to reach $55 trillion by 2055.

Bush said that neither the Democratic or Republican side of the political aisle actually has a solid plan to pay for the debt.

Trump's second term has also included nuclear talks with Iran.

Bush reiterated that the tangible impact mostly lies in federal deregulation.

title: Canada Votes, With an Eye on Trump’s Trade Policies
content: The two leading candidates, Pierre Poilievre and Mark Carney, both plan to fight the U.S., its largest trading partner, over tariffs. But who would be more successful as relations grow icy?
resumen:
Canadians voted on Monday to determine which political party forms their next government. The federal election has turned into a referendum on which of the two contenders — Prime Minister Mark Carney of the Liberal Party or Pierre Poilievre, leader of the Conservatives — can best handle the American president.

Carney has been the prime minister for just over a month. Both candidates have promised a tough response to President Trump’s belittling of Canada’s sovereignty and his tariffs.

Carney has emphasized his commitment to retaliatory tariffs. Poilievre has said that they are necessary to “deter” Trump’s trade attacks. Canada has imposed tariffs on imports from the United States that are expected to generate about 38 billion Canadian dollars annually, or about $27 billion.

Trump has imposed tariffs against key sectors of Canada’s industrial economy: 25 percent levies on autos, aluminum and steel, and a similar levy on goods that are outside the scope of the trade agreement among the United States, Canada and Mexico. A tariff on auto parts is scheduled to take effect on Saturday. Autos and auto parts are Canada’s largest exports to the United States outside of oil and gas.

Carney made his first trip as prime minister to meet with leaders in Britain and Europe. Canada has a free-trade agreement with Europe. Poilievre has pushed to build a pipeline across Canada to ship oil and liquefied natural gas to Europe. Canada currently exports more than 80 percent of its energy to the United States. Carney has also suggested finding new energy markets and building pipelines.

Carney has suggested the creation of “all-in-Canada” parts manufacturing network.

Carney says his experience as a central banker and in private investment (he has a doctorate in economics, worked at Goldman Sachs and was chairman at Brookfield Asset Management and at Bloomberg) makes him the ideal negotiator and economic crisis manager. Poilievre has not focused as directly on the trade war.

Polls show the Liberals slightly ahead of the Conservatives in the popular vote, but the Liberals are likely to have a strong majority of the seats in the House of Commons to form the next government.

title: How Trump, Trudeau and Tariffs Upended Canada’s Political Landscape
content: After nearly a decade in power, the Liberal Party seemed destined to be swept out on a wave of anti-incumbency sentiment. Then events took a surprising turn.
resumen:
Until January, polls suggested that the Conservative Party would regain power from the Liberals in any Canadian election held this year. Two things overturned that expectation: the resignation of Justin Trudeau as prime minister and President Trump’s trade war with Canada, along with his threat to annex the country and make it the 51st state by sowing economic chaos.

Mr. Trump pulled back from his initial threat of tariffs on everything imported from Canada, but he has imposed several measures that hit key sectors of Canada’s economy: a 25 percent tariff on automobiles, aluminum and steel, and a similar one on Canadian exports that do not qualify as North American goods under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, which he signed during his first term in office. An auto parts tariff of 25 percent is scheduled to take effect on Saturday. Last week, Mr. Trump suggested that the automobile tariffs, which are reduced based on their U.S.-made content, could be increased. He offered no specifics.

Autos and auto parts are Canada’s largest exports to the United States, outside oil and gas.

Under Mr. Trudeau, Canada placed retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods coming into Canada that are expected to generate 30 billion Canadian dollars, about $22 billion, in revenue over a year.

After becoming prime minister in March, Mark Carney imposed an additional 8 billion Canadian dollars, about $5.7 billion, in tariffs, including a 25 percent levy on autos made in the United States — but not on auto parts. Automakers with assembly lines in Canada will still largely be able to bring in American-made cars of those brands duty free.

Travel to the United States has declined sharply. Government-owned liquor stores in several provinces removed American beer, wine and whiskey from their shelves. As calls for boycotts of American products grew, Canadian manufacturers hurried to adorn their packaging with maple leaves and Canadian flags.

Both Mr. Carney, who also succeeded Mr. Trudeau as the Liberal Party leader, and Pierre Poilievre, the Conservative leader and the other major contender in the election, have adopted a hard line when it comes to the U.S. president.

In a conversation with Mr. Trump, in March, Mr. Carney said that the president had agreed to begin economic and security negotiations with whoever emerges as prime minister. During those talks, Mr. Carney said during a televised debate, “the starting point has to be one of strength.” He added: “It has to show that we have control of our own economic destiny.”

Throughout the campaign, Mr. Carney, who was a governor of the Bank of Canada and later of the Bank of England, has sought to emphasize that his background in the financial world makes him the ideal candidate to tackle both Mr. Trump and the economic challenges his tariffs pose.

When asked how he will deal with Mr. Trump, Mr. Poilievre, a lifelong politician, usually responds by saying that he will first tackle what he views as problems the Liberals have created within Canada. “I would cut taxes, red tape and approve our resource projects so that we can get our goods to market and bring home the jobs so we can stand up to President Trump from a position of strength,” he said during the debate.

Mr. Trump’s auto tariffs had an immediate impact. A factory in Windsor, Ontario, where Stellantis makes Chrysler minivans and Dodge muscle cars, was shut down for two weeks while the company considered its options. The association of auto parts makers said that its members had already laid off several thousand workers in Ontario.

There have also been a small number of layoffs in the steel industry.

The threatened tariff on auto parts may have a profound effect. Auto parts makers employ more people than the automakers’ assembly lines. Many parts companies are small, sometimes family-owned businesses without the financial resilience of multinational car manufacturers.

Both leaders, but Mr. Poilievre in particular, have promoted the construction of oil and gas pipelines to make it easier to ship fuel to Europe. They have not offered any specifics about what companies, if any, are interested in those projects or how they would be financed.

Mr. Poilievre also said he would accelerate environmental reviews and consultations with Indigenous groups for natural resource projects. Environmental groups and Indigenous leaders have criticized the proposal and questioned its legality.

For the auto sector, Mr. Carney has proposed to create an “all-in-Canada” system in which cars are assembled in Canada using Canadian parts made from Canadian steel and aluminum. He has not said how he would persuade automakers to go along with the plan.

Mr. Carney has also promised to set aside 2 billion Canadian dollars to help the auto industry adjust to U.S. tariffs and vowed that the money collected from retaliatory tariffs would be used to help companies and workers disrupted by the trade war. He has not specified what that help would involve.

Canadian manufacturers are battling economic headwinds amid a global trade war. Manufacturers are exploring options, including changes to their supply chain partners, transitioning product lines, and temporary layoffs, but are also calling for things they need, in the form of tax relief, trade barrier changes, and more transparency in how the reciprocal tariff revenue will be distributed.

content: You are probably as bored listening to me babble about Trump, Trade, and Tariffs as I am equally weary of writing about it. However, my obsessive quest to slay Nonsense drives my “Pursuit of Truth.” ...

title: Trump is softening his tariff talk. But the damage may already be done
content: Evidence is mounting that tariffs have curtailed economic activity and will soon push prices up, even if the effects will take time to be broadly felt ...
resumen: With 14 months remaining before the United States’ 250th birthday on July 4, 2026, Stacy Blake should be placing big orders with the Chinese factories that supply her fireworks company in St. Joseph, Missouri, but she’s not, and she blames President Donald Trump’s tariffs. The trade war is causing U.S. orders to dry up, and Chinese fireworks factories have begun shutting down, threatening to disrupt the industry’s production schedule, leading to serious shortages, said Blake, co-owner of Schneitter Fireworks & Importing, who is also president of the National Fireworks Association. Very little production is happening, and they have halted it. The president spent much of last week softening his tariff rhetoric, saying that “a fair deal” with China was possible and insisted that he had spoken with Chinese President Xi Jinping “numerous times,” which the Chinese government denied. Trade talks with dozens of other countries “are going very well,” Trump said, adding that he was “very close to a deal” with Japan. The economy has been damaged, and it could take some time to learn precisely what effect the experiment with import taxes has had. Constance Hunter, chief economist at the Economist Intelligence Unit, said, “You can’t put the toothpaste back into the tube — once you squeeze it, it’s out.” Evidence is mounting that tariffs have curtailed economic activity and will soon push prices higher. Trump’s tariffs on goods from China have disrupted trans-Pacific supply chains. U.S. officials are alarmed by companies’ dwindling inventories of critical raw-earth metals necessary for a range of economic activity; Beijing restricted the metals this month. In the three weeks since the tariffs took effect, ocean-container bookings from China to the U.S. are down by more than 60%, said Ryan Petersen, founder and CEO of Flexport. Cargo carriers that bring Asian goods to the Port of Los Angeles have canceled 20 port calls next month, more than three times as many as last month, according to port data. Torsten Slok, chief economist for Apollo Global Management, said the consequence will be “empty shelves in U.S. stores in a few weeks and COVID-like shortages for consumers and for firms using Chinese products as intermediate goods.” Fewer goods reaching American shores will mean higher prices on the goods that are in stores — as well as less work for dockworkers and truck drivers. “Significant” layoffs in trucking, logistics and retail are likely as soon as May, Slok said. Jason Furman, a Harvard University professor who served as a senior economist in the Obama administration, said, “It feels like this slow-motion wave that’s coming toward us, but not here yet.” The Philadelphia Fed’s manufacturing survey showed one of the biggest monthly drops on record, surpassed only by the start of the 2020 pandemic and the 2008 Great Recession. Business investment is also cratering in response to the uncertainty caused by the tariffs, say Furman and other economists. Bill Adams, chief economist for Comerica Bank, wrote in a client note Friday, “The U.S. economy is pointed in a dangerous direction. The further the economy goes down this path, the higher the risk of a recession.” Trump has signaled a desire to reach an agreement with China to remove drastic economic restrictions. He has emphasized that his advisers are negotiating with dozens of other countries, too. The president often claims to have a personal relationship with Xi. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent last week told reporters that it was “both a blessing and a curse that the strongest relationship (between the two nations) is at the very top.” Myron Brilliant, a senior counselor at DGA Group, said, “They have a different approach. They’re bottom-up. Trump likes to work negotiations top-down.” The United States is advancing toward a deal with India, said Eswar Prasad, a Cornell University professor who served in a senior role at the International Monetary Fund. The administration is pushing India to lower its tariffs on American agricultural products. Bessent has projected optimism about reaching deals quickly with partners such as South Korea. Newt Gingrich, a Trump ally who served as speaker of the House from 1995 to1999, said, “The Trump technique, if you read his two books on negotiating, is to go way out and then gradually pull back — he never goes small and then pushes out — and he’s done that his whole career.” Goods from China now face tariffs of 145%, and China has retaliated with its own economic restrictions. One person briefed on the White House’s thinking, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said, “They never wanted tariffs that high on China. Trump just went tit-for-tat with him. That’s him as a person — he wants to treat them as they treat us.” Even if Trump eventually does roll back duties on Chinese-made goods to 60%, the overall U.S. average tariff rate would sit at 16% — a sharp rise from the pre-trade war figure of around 2.2%, according to a JPMorgan Chase analysis. That increase would be more than 10 times what the U.S. experienced during Trump’s first term and would represent a tax hike of nearly $500 billion on American importers, according to the investment bank. Japan is expected to resist U.S. requests to limit automobile exports, said two people familiar with the matter, speaking on the condition of anonymity. EU Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis told the Wall Street Journal the EU won’t negotiate changes to its value-added tax or agricultural subsidies. Prasad, citing conversations with economic officials in four countries, said U.S. trading partners are largely in the dark about key elements of a potential deal. One foreign diplomat, speaking on the condition of anonymity, expressed concern that any deal reached with Treasury or Commerce officials could be later undercut by Trump. Some trading partners are also wary of agreeing to the administration’s demands only to see Trump impose additional tariffs on their businesses later this year. Almost all of the fireworks that Americans purchase for personal use are made in China; three-quarters of the pyrotechnics featured in more elaborate community celebrations are Chinese. In 2019, recognizing the lack of domestic production, Trump exempted the industry from his first China tariffs. Importers who cannot afford 145% taxes have told their Chinese suppliers to freeze shipments, which could mean some consumer favorites for celebrating the July Fourth holiday this year will be hard to find, said Blake. Without immediate relief from Trump’s tariffs, American importers will miss their turn in the Chinese production line for 2026. Fireworks factories will soon enter their annual summer shutdown. And when they reopen, they are scheduled to fill European orders before producing what Chinese consumers demand. Blake said, “It’s very crucial that we start manufacturing in China right now.”

The U.S. slapped a whopping 145 percent tariff on China.

Trump insists that negotiations are progressing, and told reporters earlier this month that a deal could be reached with China within three to four weeks.

Trump was quoted in TIME as saying that Xi had called him to discuss trade.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told ABC News’ Martha Raddatz in an interview on Sunday: “I don’t know if President Trump has spoken with President Xi.”

A poll from the Washington Post-ABC News-Ipsos released Sunday found that more than seven in 10 Americans rate the economy as “not so good” or “poor,” and 53 percent say economic conditions have worsened since Trump returned to office in January.

Bessent spoke with Chinese officials last week during the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said that talks between U.S. and Chinese officials were taking place “every day” in an interview Sunday with CNN’s “State of the Union.”

China has said that formal talks on Trump’s latest tariffs have not officially started.

Trump also told TIME that he’s negotiated 200 trade deals with countries that are seeking to stave off the return of so-called reciprocal tariffs in July.

Rollins said there are “100 countries that are knocking on the door.”

Bessent acknowledged negotiations with only a handful of countries. “There’s 17 important trading partners, and we have a process in place, over the next 90 days, to negotiate with them, especially the – with the Asian countries,” he said on Sunday.

Canadians are hitting the polls today for federal elections that have been heavily shaped by Trump’s tariff threats and claims of wanting to make Canada the 51st state in the union, reports POLITICO’s Jonathan Martin.

The contest is coming down to the Liberal Party’s Mark Carney and Pierre Poilievre of the Conservative Party, who held a significant 26-point advantage in late 2024.

Now, Carney enjoys a narrow lead over his conservative rival.

Trump agreed on Saturday to meet with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

Trump said his tariff plans could help eliminate taxes on people who make less than $200,000 a year.

The Trump administration claims to have collected nearly $16 billion during the month of April in “customs and excise taxes,” according to data from the Treasury Department.

The Senate Finance Committee is holding a hearing on Wednesday for Trump’s nominee to lead U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Rodney Scott, Chair Mike Crapo (R-Idaho) announced last week.

title: Trump Proposes to Recognise Crimea – Law, Power, and the Limits of the International System…
content: Finley is a Slugger reader from Belfast The international state system is often spoken of as if it were fixed, neutral, and inherently aligned with peace and prosperity. It is none of those things. It ...
resumen: The international state system is often perceived as fixed, neutral, and aligned with peace and prosperity, but it is a pragmatic structure shaped by power dynamics and strategic needs. The Peace of Westphalia in 1648 marked a shift towards sovereign equality, enabling coexistence without ideological conformity. This allowed Europe to stabilize and expand, but also permitted war as an instrument of state policy and territorial revision through force. The current international system, shaped after World War II, seeks to constrain conflict through a legal and normative architecture that elevates territorial integrity and non-intervention. This system, however, can create tensions by refusing to recognize strategic rivalries, potentially freezing conflict and inhibiting reconciliation. The international system is an evolving political framework shaped by competing interests, security concerns, and historical compromises. The tension between these dynamics and contemporary international law often leads to contradictions. The belief that peace and prosperity necessarily go together, and that international law is the vessel for both, overlooks the many times in history—and in the present—when legal restraint undermines prosperity, or when the pursuit of peace through law fails to account for the brutal logics of power and security. The rigidity of the system today leaves little space for political recalibration. When powerful states perceive the legal framework as unresponsive to their existential interests, they are increasingly willing to ignore or override it. The tension between legalism and state interest is most pronounced in security. States will always act to secure their survival and strategic interests, even when this conflicts with international law. The Russian annexation of Crimea in 2014 and the U.S. invasion of Iraq in 2003 are examples of states acting in accordance with their perceived national interests and security needs, disregarding international law. The current international order often imposes a stark contradiction: states are told to pursue their security within the bounds of international law, yet these laws themselves are often vague, inconsistent, or selectively enforced. The structural limits of the current international system are most clearly exposed in the two defining rivalries of our time: between Russia and NATO, and between the United States and China. Donald Trump's return to office has reignited debate over the future direction of American foreign policy, particularly with respect to Russia. Trump has signalled an interest in normalising relations with Moscow, departing from the bipartisan consensus that has sought to isolate Russia politically and economically following its annexation of Crimea and intervention in Ukraine. Trump’s approach raises a fundamental question about the international system: should conflicts between states, once concluded in practical terms, remain indefinitely open as moral and legal grievances? Or should states be free to recalibrate relations based on strategic interest, economic opportunity, and evolving geopolitical conditions? A Westphalian system—or at least one guided by its principles—would allow strategic adjustments that reflect changing circumstances. The present legalist system, by contrast, makes such normalisation extremely difficult. The logic of indefinite punishment and diplomatic quarantine does not just harm the targeted state; it can also harm those enforcing the measures. The true challenge, then, is not whether to uphold a rules-based system or to descend into chaos, but whether we can design an international framework that makes room for politics, allows states to adjust after crisis, and accepts that peace—when it comes—is not always delivered through law, but often through the hard choices of diplomacy and the recalibration of interests.

title: 'Trump is playing his hand impulisvely, while Xi Jinping is far more methodical'
content: OP-ED. The confrontation between the US and China shows no signs of ending, even though recent statements from both sides attempt to ease tensions over tariffs, writes economist Claude Meyer.
resumen: Donald Trump was the first to back down in the tariff war against China when he admitted to the press on April 22 that the surcharges imposed on Beijing were "very high" and would "come down substantially." He had already faced a double setback during the week of April 7: the market downturn sanctioned the economic nonsense of his all-out tariff war, and China, stung in its national pride, responded sharply with retaliatory measures. Which explains the American billionaire's umpteenth about-turn on April 9, in the form of a double backflip. Magnanimously, he offered a 90-day pause to all those who rushed to negotiate – as he put it crudely – but with one major exception: Chinese products would be subjected to a stratospheric 145% tax, which was later abandoned in a new twist on April 12 for electronic products. The reason for this colossal and prohibitive tariff? Beijing dared to respond to the previous tariff by applying the same 84% rate to American exports. On April 11, the Chinese government announced an increase from 84% to 125% tariffs on American products. Beijing then declared: "High tariffs(...) runs counter to basic economic principles and common sense, and is simply an act of unilateral bullying and coercion," reiterating that China will "fight to the end."

title: Finnish government invokes Nazi-collaborationist traditions as it backs Trump, builds up military
content: The Finnish government is set to leave the Ottawa Land Mine Treaty and has struck a deal to sell icebreakers to the US in support of Trump’s military build-up against Russia and China in the Arctic.
resumen:
In recent weeks, Finland’s right-wing government has announced measures supporting NATO and the Trump administration’s expansionist agenda. It plans to leave the Ottawa Treaty banning the use of landmines, to sell the United States icebreaker ships to militarise the Arctic, and raise the military budget by billions of euros. On March 29, Finnish president Alexander Stubb of the conservative National Coalition Party (NCP) paid an unofficial visit to Trump at his Mar-a-Lago resort. Over seven hours of dining and golf, the two discussed the NATO war in Ukraine, expanding European militarism, and according to Finnish public broadcaster YLE, Finland’s historical alliance with Nazi Germany during the invasion of the Soviet Union. Stubb bragged, “President Trump independently raised the icebreaker idea several times during the day, and that is a good thing for Finland.”

US vice president JD Vance travelled to Greenland, held by NATO ally Denmark, and called to annex it. Stubb told other European powers that another main topic of discussion was the NATO war in Ukraine. He pushed Trump to not trust Putin, and to negotiate a ceasefire by Easter that would allow Ukrainian membership in NATO and the deployment of US-backed European peacekeepers along with threats of additional sanctions. Finland, along with other Baltic and Nordic countries, has been one of the strongest proponents of the NATO war against Russia in Ukraine.

Finland and Sweden used the war as a pretext to drop their longstanding neutrality and join NATO in 2023 and 2024, respectively. Since the 2023 parliamentary elections, Finland has been governed by a right-wing coalition led by Stubb’s NCP and including the far-right Finns Party, the Swedish People’s Party, and the Christian Democrats. In neighbouring Sweden, a similar governing coalition relies on the fascistic Sweden Democrats for a parliamentary majority.

In justifying their support for Trump, the Finnish government has repeatedly spoken positively of Finland’s alliance with the Nazis during World War II. A key theme of Stubb’s remarks in Kiev on the third anniversary of Russia’s US-provoked invasion of Ukraine was that it was a tragedy that Finland, and by implication its ally, Nazi Germany, lost to the Soviet Union. He stated, “Now, in World War II, Finland had to accept a peace with Stalin.” These sentiments were echoed by foreign minister Elina Valtonen (NCP) last month in a London speech.

The Finnish government participated in countless historic crimes, including organising a Waffen-SS battalion that carried out war crimes as part of the Nazi invasion of Soviet Ukraine. The Finnish government received advanced notice of Hitler’s Operation Barbarossa, the June 1941 invasion of the Soviet Union that claimed at least 27 million Soviet citizens’ lives. In 1944, with Nazi Germany’s ultimate defeat all but assured, Finland concluded a separate peace agreement with the Soviet Union.

Amid the current anti-Russian agitation, the government has enacted emergency anti-refugee measures, closing the border with Russia. Embracing the far-right propaganda of the Finns Party, it claimed that the attempt of a mere 1,300 Middle Eastern asylum seekers to cross into Finland from Russia was a national emergency. Violating the basic democratic right of asylum, it has applied for an extension of its emergency border closure into 2026, scapegoating immigrants to divert popular anger from its programme of austerity and war.

The Finnish government reacted to the US-provoked war on Russia in Ukraine by raising military spending, presenting itself as an essential partner in future wars against Russia and China. Stubb consistently presents support for the Ukrainian regime as essential for the strategic goal of confronting China. On April 1, Prime Minister Petteri Orpo (NCP) said Finland would raise military spending by a further €3 billion, and join Poland, Lithuania, Estonia, and Latvia in withdrawing from the Ottawa convention, which prohibits the use of antipersonnel landmines.

The right-wing Finnish government is on pace for military spending to triple by the end of the decade. In 2020, the Finnish defence budget amounted to €3.2 billion. It currently stands at €6.2 billion, and the recently announced increase will see it rise to €9 billion by 2029, or 3 percent of gross domestic product. In December 2021, Helsinki ordered 64 US-built F-35 fighter jets at a cost of $9.4 billion, the country’s largest ever single military purchase.

Finland has agreed to purchase €312 million of military equipment from Israel. To pay for this, the government is enacting deeply unpopular cuts to social spending. A January poll showed that 54 percent of Finns disapproved of the spending cuts. Orpo’s government has committed to a €9 billion fiscal adjustment agenda, including spending cuts and adjustments to value added tax.

title: 100 days for the history books: Trump takes US-Mexico relations back to the 19th century
content: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum has cautiously and efficiently handled 100 days of an uncertainty that is far from over. Mexico has sidestepped the onerous tariffs imposed in other regions of the ...
resumen:
In 1975, a survey asked Mexican schoolchildren which country inspired the least sympathy in them, and the majority responded: the United States. Another question asked them if they had to live outside of Mexico, which place would they choose. The answer: the United States. U.S. President Donald Trump is shattering the trust built between two nations with a history fraught with quarrels and agreements. International experts call it a new paradigm, alluding to the intrusion of opportunistic politics into trade agreements. Trump’s first term shook the pillars that supported a decades-long understanding, and the current version of the same president is dramatically rocking the boat. Mexico, America’s largest trading partner, is already looking for domestic economic solutions to overcome a crisis that threatens to completely change bilateral relations.

The 1,954-mile border separating both countries has witnessed territorial wars, but also multiple commercial and human exchanges. What was once viewed as a labor force is now seen as undesirable immigration by the Trump administration; the same goes for drug trafficking.

Erika Pani, a professor at the Colegio de México, explains that the trade agreements left out political disputes, which were dealt with separately. Now the conversation is tainted, and the negotiation of tariffs is based on either fentanyl or migration. Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum has cautiously and efficiently handled 100 days of an uncertainty that is far from over. Mexico has sidestepped the onerous tariffs imposed in other regions of the world and, for now, faces only the 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum, as well as on certain products outside the trade agreement. Auto parts are a big concern and a major problem for its big business, vehicle assembly. A 25% tariff has been planned for these components.

Martha Bárcena, who served as Mexico’s ambassador to the United States during the last two years of Trump’s first term, says that if you break the integration of the automotive sector, you break the very reason for the USMCA. The Republican president’s whims have Mexico in a state of turmoil.

The economic and diplomatic teams are sleeping on their heels, while at the same time, curious political windows are opening, such as the worldwide fame Claudia Sheinbaum has gained with her “cool-headed” strategy to confront the insatiable blond-haired magnate. The opposition is closing ranks against the danger from the north, and governors from all parties are joining forces in the capital’s great square to make a show of unity and strength. The asymmetry in relations between the two countries remains unchanged: the south is the weak partner.

Bárcena says that the USMCA is in intensive care and that Trump is being more drastic and chaotic than expected and is undoing the international order inherited from World War II and dismantling the security of global trade.

The Mexican government wants to reorganize its basket, given that 83% of its exports go to the United States, where it sent goods worth more than $505 billion in 2024. No other country in the world sells more to Uncle Sam. Sheinbaum has rallied the national business community around a strategy that seeks to increase domestic production for its own internal market.

Estefanía Cruz Lera of the Center for North American Research at UNAM says that Trump has placed the government on a reactive policy. She says that we must look for opportunities in this context and seek to rebuild ourselves in some way and rethink long-term relations.

Some of the changes being proposed today arise from demands made by Trump, who imposes penalties on those who negotiate with other countries beyond what he prescribes, such as auto parts with China or oil with Venezuela. In Mexico, one of the major changes in these 100 days has come in the area of security, with Trump making tariffs conditional on combating drug trafficking and the presence of fentanyl in his country. Sheinbaum’s administration has deployed a completely new security strategy, distinct from that of her predecessor, and attacks on drug lords are occurring daily. In recent months, more than 18,000 people have been arrested for high-impact crimes, 144 tons of drugs have been seized, including two million fentanyl pills, and 839 clandestine laboratories have been destroyed.

Immigration is a constant point of contention, given the supremacist drift and contempt displayed by the current U.S. administration. Sheinbaum has raised her voice somewhat, most recently to order a change to the law that allows foreign countries to broadcast political propaganda on Mexican television stations, where Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem has deployed a racist anti-immigrant campaign.

Cruz Lera says that the United States is once again using the trade relationship as a political weapon, and in Mexico they appeal to Mexican sentiment.

Trump has traded the common destiny of both nations for Manifest Destiny, that 19th-century political doctrine that relied on the United States’s inherent letter of marque for territorial expansion. Mexico then lost a large portion of its territory.

Pani says that General Lázaro Cárdenas and President Roosevelt established a “special relationship” that, after the end of World War II, implanted in the consciences “the mutual need” that both countries share, although it will always be asymmetrical.

Bárcena says that Trump has shattered this balance by frequently alluding to “historical aberrations” in his speeches. She adds that Trump has gone back to the 19th century without seeing the gray areas of history.

Bárcena laments that Trump’s actions will undo years in which the population was changing the psychological relationship between the two countries, from seeing the United States as an invader to treating it as a trading partner and investor. Pani believes that the mechanisms for conflict resolution are broken at the moment, but, although very different, they are neighbors and are destined to understand each other.

title: The tariff is the message
content: By Jam Magdaleno THE PROBLEM with the MAGA analysis of US President Donald Trump’s tariff decisions is not that it misunderstands economics. It’s that economics was never the point to begin with. In ...
resumen: The problem with the MAGA analysis of US President Donald Trump’s tariff decisions is that economics was never the point. In Trump’s America, the economic consequences of protectionist policy are an afterthought. The decision to impose tariffs is not judged by efficiency or output, but by its symbolic weight. It is, first and foremost, a semiotic act: an assertion of sovereignty, vengeance against globalism, a performance of strength. Before the new 10% universal import tariff took effect, Trump’s supporters had already declared victory. Manufacturing would come home. American industry would rise again. Similar tariffs in his first term resulted in job losses, higher prices, and stalled output. The New York Fed found US businesses and consumers bore nearly all the cost of the 2018 tariffs. The Tax Foundation and other economists warn that a universal tariff could cost American households hundreds to thousands of dollars more each year, depending on income level and consumption — functioning like an indirect tax on consumers. The Center for American Progress (CAP) estimates that his 2025 universal tariff will cost households an additional $1,500 per year. To the MAGA base, tariffs are not about cost-benefit, they are about retribution. 16 independent Nobel laureate economists sounded the alarm on Trump’s economic policies before the 2024 presidential election — even conservative economists have called the policy what it is: a populist tax hike. Thomas Sowell has long warned that protectionist sentiment appeals to the desire to “do something” in response to national decline, regardless of whether it works. Former Bush adviser Douglas Holtz-Eakin now calls Trump’s plan “inflationary by design.” Larry Kudlow, once Trump’s own economic advisor, has described it as a “misguided fantasy.” MAGA doesn’t care if the economics don’t work. The tariff is never evaluated in isolation — it is always subsumed within a broader worldview. If it fails, it’s because of sabotage, globalist betrayal, or disloyal bureaucrats. If it succeeds, it proves Trump was right all along. There is no test that could disprove the narrative, because the narrative comes first. When Trump threatened to impose 25% tariffs on Canadian auto exports earlier this year, the administration announced a “pause.” Mark Carney, Canada’s Prime Minister, and a seasoned economist, had quietly increased Canadian holdings of US Treasury bonds to over $350 billion. Then he coordinated with Japan and EU nations, signaling that if Trump escalated, they would begin a slow sell-off of US debt. Trump blinked. The MAGA base didn’t see surrender; they saw strategy. They claimed Trump was “reassessing,” “focusing on China,” or “outmaneuvering the globalists.” When Trump walked back his threat to impose auto tariffs on the EU and Japan in 2018, the move was reframed as a brilliant pressure tactic. When the US-China “Phase One” trade deal failed to deliver structural reforms and China fell short on purchase commitments, it was spun as groundwork for a tougher second phase — which never came. When Trump replaced NAFTA with the USMCA, a deal nearly identical in substance, his supporters hailed it as a total overhaul. Economists debate results; MAGA asserts meaning. The tariffs are not tools — they are declarations. They signal moral clarity. A desire to decouple from a rigged system. To punish those who “cheated” America. In Trump’s America, even when the policies fail, outcomes are not seen as policy failures but as evidence of a hard, necessary war. In 2018, US farmers lost billions in export revenue after China retaliated against Trump’s tariffs, yet many remained loyal, describing their sacrifice as part of a patriotic stand against exploitation. When prices rose for goods like appliances and automobiles, supporters said they were willing to pay more if it meant buying American. Even when Ford reported $1 billion in losses due to steel tariffs, or when factory hiring slowed amid uncertainty, the suffering was recast as martyrdom — proof that Trump was taking on a rigged global system. Institutions like the New York Fed and the Tax Foundation showed that consumers bore the brunt of Trump’s tariffs and would continue to do so under his 2025 plan, yet these findings were dismissed as elite handwringing. The MAGA movement is not operating on the axis of efficiency. It is driven by a desire for justice as they define it — economic nationalism not as policy, but as redemption. The tariffs are not anchored in the real economy. They are anchored in a story. A story of betrayal, of comeback, of righteous struggle. Jam Magdaleno is a political communications expert and the head of the Information & Communications unit at the Foundation for Economic Freedom.

Since Trump’s return to office on 20 January, the dollar index has fallen nearly 9%, its worst performance in the first 100 days of any presidency since the Nixon era, when the US abandoned the Bretton Woods system.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has ruled out a recession in the world’s largest economy.

As several central banks gear up for their monetary policy reviews in May, markets are largely anticipating a cautious tone.

The US Federal Reserve faces mounting political pressure from President Donald Trump to cut rates.

In Japan, the central bank is expected to keep rates steady, wary of a weakening yen and external shocks, even as domestic inflation inches closer to its 2% target.

The Bank of England and Bank Indonesia are also expected to hold policy rates unchanged.

California's economy grew 6.01% in 2024.

As of March 2025, the state’s unemployment rate stood at 5.3%, higher than the national average of 4.2%.

The IMF has raised alarms about rising global debt, forecasting a significant increase in the coming years.

According to its April 2025 Fiscal Monitor, global public debt is set to rise by 2.8 percentage points in 2025 to 95.1% of GDP.

In the US, debt could rise to 122.5% of GDP in 2025.

China's debt is expected to rise to 96.3% of GDP, while India's is projected to reach 80.4%.

The passing of Pope Francis has brought an end to a 12-year-long papacy.

At the time of his death, Pope Francis was the second-oldest pope to serve in over 400 years.

title: Reasserting trade discipline in a post-Trump order
content: Countries must stand firm on trade commitments, pushing back against short-term disruptions to ensure long-term economic prosperity.
resumen:
Global trade faces unprecedented uncertainty due to unpredictable US trade policies, including tariff impositions and withdrawal from multilateral agreements. To prevent further economic destabilisation, major economies must unite to reaffirm their commitment to existing trade rules. Collective action is essential to prevent the breakdown of international commerce and ensure stability and prosperity for all nations in the long run.

Leaders of a critical mass of the world’s economies need to communicate to reaffirm their support for a rules-based environment for trade. Swift action is urgently needed to avoid the disruption already caused by US President Donald Trump leading to disastrous global damage.

The new US administration has unilaterally abandoned WTO disciplines, along with provisions of trade agreements with other partners. It has imposed — then temporarily deferred — high tariff barriers against all other economies. These actions breach either or both of the United States’s commitments to the WTO and its agreements with trading partners. They have created extreme uncertainty about future trade policy. While the US economy will suffer the greatest damage from these erratic decisions, all other economies will suffer high costs of adjustment to new, uncertain circumstances.

Confidence in a largely rules-based system of international commerce — which has led to huge benefits to the world for the past 80 years — has been severely shaken. The system could break down completely if other governments followed the United States’s example of disregarding their current policy commitments to international partners.

Retaliating against the United States may not be the smartest way to minimise the economic damage inflicted by its disruptive actions, but some retaliation may be impossible to avoid for political reasons. Several trading partners have already, or are considering, retaliating against the United States, sometimes in ways which also breach WTO disciplines. But retaliation against the offender need not be accompanied by breaking commitments to other economies.

At the same time, several governments are rushing to strike ‘deals’ with the United States to exempt them from at least some of the tariffs they might face very soon. There is grave danger that some of these deals could be on terms which break existing commitments to third parties. Some US officials have already suggested they would demand others restrict their trade with China. WTO disciplines and the terms of existing bilateral and regional trade agreements could be cast aside in hopes of placating a reckless United States.

There are some hopeful signs. China’s Ministry of Commerce stated that ‘attempts to trade the interests of others for tariff exemptions are doomed to fail and will ultimately harm all parties involved’.

A catastrophic breakdown of the rules-based system might still be avoided if other major economies followed this lead. It may then be possible to preserve at least the most important features of the WTO and other bilateral and regional agreements. A critical mass of major economies, including China, could reaffirm that they will abide by existing agreements on the conduct of international commerce, while reserving the right to retaliate against the United States.

Such a restated commitment would be highly welcome, but not sufficient to ensure confidence. Experience tells us that ‘standstill’ agreements are hard to sustain. At a time when all economies need to find new export markets, it will be very hard to avoid special forms of assistance to some sectors and some firms may decide to sell exports at prices below domestic prices. Some governments are then likely to claim that others are providing ‘unfair’ subsidies or allowing the dumping of products to compete in their markets. Other breaches of commitments in rapidly changing conditions could be due to pressure from vested interests, or a misinterpretation of often complex provisions in some agreements. An agreement to abide by existing commitments could become meaningless unless it is backed by a speedy and binding dispute settlement procedure.

Governments which make commitments in good faith to abide by already agreed disciplines on international commerce should also be prepared to set up and to abide by decisions of an agreed dispute settlement procedure. An effective procedure could draw on the precedents already set, including the Multi-Party Interim Appeal Arbitration Arrangement already adopted by some governments and regional trade agreements.

Urgent communications could lead to a joint declaration by leaders of major economies. This could state that international commerce, other than with the United States, would continue to be consistent with already agreed commitments. Any trade disputes among the signatories would also be settled using an effective and binding dispute settlement procedure. Such a declaration would reduce current uncertainty — providing an assurance that most international commerce can continue to be based on existing rules.

Before Trump’s international policy upheavals, such reassurance could have been expected from all G20 leaders. But now, a new group must be assembled. That group would ideally include most of the G20 while inviting others ready to join in issuing a declaration. All other governments could sign on later if they wanted to help stabilise a rules-based environment for international commerce.

Restoring some degree of confidence would reduce the prospect of governments accepting rushed deals with the United States on terms which create additional departures from existing commitments. Declaring a shared refusal to add to damage already caused would also create a breathing space to strengthen the foundations of a rules-based international environment for trade and broader international commerce.

Because any WTO reform requires consensus among very many governments and has failed to keep up with the issues raised by the ever-widening range of other international commerce, it is unlikely to be able to keep up with the currently rapidly changing geopolitical environment.

In the longer term, it may be possible to reconstruct a sufficiently nimble international institution with potentially worldwide coverage. That effort could build on the best features of the WTO and those of existing regional agreements including the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership or Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership.

Andrew Elek is Research Associate at the Crawford School of Public Policy, The Australian National University. He was the inaugural Chair of APEC Senior Officials in 1989.

resumen: During his first 100 days in office, President Donald Trump has made tariffs a central part of his policy. He’s made dozens of tariff announcements starting on Jan. 20, imposing - and sometimes then pausing - tariffs on other countries. Readers who responded to an unscientific MLive survey showed a split in Michigan with some blasting the tariffs strategy and others pointing to the potential long-term benefits touted by Trump. Trump says these tariffs are necessary to combat a continued global trade imbalance, return lost U.S. manufacturing jobs and staunch a flow of illicit drugs into the country. Trump has acknowledged that there may be some short-term pain as a result. Some economists have expressed concern that continued tariffs could worsen inflation. Given Michigan’s position as a border state with trading partner Canada, an auto industry hub and agricultural exporter, MLive decided to ask readers about their thoughts on Trump administration tariffs. The responses were mixed. Respondents on both sides agreed that implementing tariffs will likely be a long-term strategy, but differed in opinion on if it will ultimately pay off. Approximately 58% of surveyed readers who reached out via social media or MLive survey said they do not think tariffs will lead to long-term gain. Another 41% of respondents said they do think Trump’s stance on tariffs will pay off. Trump has announced and paused tariffs on Mexico and Canada multiple times. He’s also set global reciprocal tariffs, or a 10% baseline tax on imports from all countries, with additional higher tax rates for dozens of other nations. The reciprocal tariffs above 10% were paused for 90 days on April 9. The highest tariff rate now imposed by Trump against any country is the 145% tariff on China. With some new tariffs already in place and others with the potential to apply soon, many respondents who reached out to MLive - either through the survey or on social media - expressed concern about the possibility of higher prices and inflation. A recent Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research poll found that roughly half of U.S. adults surveyed believe that Trump’s trade policies will increase prices “a lot,” while another 3 in 10 thought prices could go up “somewhat.” Trump’s tariff announcements have set off several dips in the stock market, which stabilized slightly after subsequent pauses. A recent report from Advantage Commercial Real Estate of Grand Rapids found that rising costs for materials like steel and aluminum will likely make constructing more industrial buildings an immediate challenge, and some West Michigan industrial companies are putting growth plans on hold.
